newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan activists in scuffle over island landing.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan activists in scuffle over island landing.

text.p: Taiwan demonstrators threw eggs and scuffled with police while trying to storm Japan's de facto embassy in Taipei on Thursday to protest against a landing by four Japanese on a disputed East China Sea island.
Ten protesters, shouting "down with Japanese militarism" and "Japan has no right to occupy the Diaoyu Islands", tried to deliver a petition to Japan's Interchange Association.
The association, which represents Tokyo in the absence of diplomatic ties, shut its gate and refused to accept the letter.

Chou Ching-chun, head of the Taiwan Diaoyu Islands Defence Action Committee, pelted the gate with his shoes. One protester, Hsiao Yun-shan, 74, fell during the scuffle and was taken to hospital with minor injuries.
No arrests were made during the protest, the second in two days in Taiwan over the islands.
The Japanese-administered islands are called Senkaku by Japan and Diaoyu by China. They are claimed by Tokyo, Beijing and Taipei.
Japanese legislator Shingo Nishimura and three other people landed on one of the islands on Tuesday.
The act drew protests from China and Taiwan and ignited nationalistic passions in Chinese communities in Hong Kong and Taiwan.
Waters surrounding the islands are rich fishing grounds and are believed to contain oil and gas reserves.
Japan has claimed the islands since 1895, while China says it has always owned them.
On Wednesday, activists stormed the visa office of the Interchange Association, pelting it with eggs and forcing staffers and visa applicants to take cover.
The dispute was rekindled last year when a right-wing group from Japan built a makeshift lighthouse on the islands.
